verses.text: In the twenty-third year of Joash son of Ahaziah king of Judah, Jehoahaz son of Jehu became king of Israel in Samaria, and he reigned seventeen years.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:1
rsbNotes.text: 13:1 twenty-third year of Joash . . . reigned seventeen years. That is, 814–798 b.c.

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the LORD by following the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he had caused Israel to commit, and he did not turn away from them.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:2
rsbNotes.text: 13:2 the sins of Jeroboam. See note 1 Kin. 12:30.

verses.text: So the LORD's anger burned against Israel, and for a long time he kept them under the power of Hazael king of Aram and Ben-Hadad his son.
Then Jehoahaz sought the LORD's favor, and the LORD listened to him, for he saw how severely the king of Aram was oppressing Israel.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:3
rsbNotes.text: 13:3 Ben-hadad the son of Hazael. That is, Ben-hadad III. For Ben-hadad I, see 1 Kin. 15:18–21; for Ben-hadad II, see 1 Kin. 20:1 note; 2 Kin. 6:24; 8:7.

verses.text: The LORD provided a deliverer for Israel, and they escaped from the power of Aram. So the Israelites lived in their own homes as they had before.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:5
rsbNotes.text: 13:5 gave Israel a savior. Much as in the time of the judges (Judg. 2:16–23), God provides temporary help from the Syrian onslaught. The deliverer is not named.

verses.text: But they did not turn away from the sins of the house of Jeroboam, which he had caused Israel to commit; they continued in them. Also, the Asherah pole remained standing in Samaria.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:6
rsbNotes.text:
13:6 the sins of the house of Jeroboam. See note 1 Kin. 12:30.

Asherah. This object was set up by Ahab (1 Kin. 16:33) and apparently was left untouched by Jehu’s reforms (2 Kin. 10:18–28).

verses.text: Nothing had been left of the army of Jehoahaz except fifty horsemen, ten chariots and ten thousand foot soldiers, for the king of Aram had destroyed the rest and made them like the dust at threshing time.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:7
rsbNotes.text: 13:7 fifty horsemen and ten chariots and ten thousand footmen. The king is left with a large number of infantry, but only a very few chariots. This crippled his ability to react quickly to a military crisis.

verses.text: As for the other events of the reign of Jehoahaz, all he did and his achievements, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
Jehoahaz rested with his fathers and was buried in Samaria. And Jehoash his son succeeded him as king.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:8
rsbNotes.text: 13:8 Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

verses.text: In the thirty-seventh year of Joash king of Judah, Jehoash son of Jehoahaz became king of Israel in Samaria, and he reigned sixteen years.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:10
rsbNotes.text: 13:10 the thirty-seventh year of Joash. That is, 798 b.c. Jehoash reigned 798–782 b.c.

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the LORD and did not turn away from any of the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he had caused Israel to commit; he continued in them.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:11
rsbNotes.text: 13:11 the sins of Jeroboam. See note 1 Kin. 12:30.

verses.text: As for the other events of the reign of Jehoash, all he did and his achievements, including his war against Amaziah king of Judah, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:12
rsbNotes.text: 13:12 Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

verses.text: Jehoash rested with his fathers, and Jeroboam succeeded him on the throne. Jehoash was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:13
rsbNotes.text: 13:13 Jeroboam. Jeroboam II ruled from 793–753 b.c., including eleven years as co-regent with his father Jehoash. Jeroboam began his independent reign when Jehoash died in 782 b.c. See 14:23–29.

verses.text: Now Elisha was suffering from the illness from which he died. Jehoash king of Israel went down to see him and wept over him. "My father! My father!" he cried. "The chariots and horsemen of Israel!"
Elisha said, "Get a bow and some arrows," and he did so.
"Take the bow in your hands," he said to the king of Israel. When he had taken it, Elisha put his hands on the king's hands.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:14
rsbNotes.text:
13:14 My father. See note 2:12.

The chariots of Israel and its horsemen. Earlier, Elisha used this expression of Elijah; now Jehoash applies the compliment to Elisha.

verses.text: "Open the east window," he said, and he opened it. "Shoot!" Elisha said, and he shot. "The LORD's arrow of victory, the arrow of victory over Aram!" Elisha declared. "You will completely destroy the Arameans at Aphek."

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:17
rsbNotes.text:
13:17 eastward. This window opened toward the region controlled by Syria (10:32, 33).

the arrow of victory over Syria. The symbolic action is a prophecy that Jehoash himself will fulfill.

Aphek. See note 1 Kin. 20:26.

verses.text: Then he said, "Take the arrows," and the king took them. Elisha told him, "Strike the ground." He struck it three times and stopped.

The man of God was angry with him and said, "You should have struck the ground five or six times; then you would have defeated Aram and completely destroyed it. But now you will defeat it only three times."

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:18
rsbNotes.text: 13:18 and stopped. Somehow Jehoash failed to perceive the inner meaning of what the prophet was urging him to do. Elisha considered that Jehoash was clearly guilty for his lack of enthusiasm.

verses.text: Elisha died and was buried. Now Moabite raiders used to enter the country every spring.

Once while some Israelites were burying a man, suddenly they saw a band of raiders; so they threw the man's body into Elisha's tomb. When the body touched Elisha's bones, the man came to life and stood up on his feet.
Hazael king of Aram oppressed Israel throughout the reign of Jehoahaz.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:20
rsbNotes.text: 13:20 Elisha died. Presumably Elisha died of old age.

verses.text: But the LORD was gracious to them and had compassion and showed concern for them because of his covenant with Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. To this day he has been unwilling to destroy them or banish them from his presence.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:23
rsbNotes.text: 13:23 because of His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Divine commitment is steadfast and eternal (cf. 1 Kin. 18:36).

verses.text: Hazael king of Aram died, and Ben-Hadad his son succeeded him as king.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:24
rsbNotes.text: 13:24 Ben-hadad. That is, Ben-hadad III (v. 3 note).

verses.text: Then Jehoash son of Jehoahaz recaptured from Ben-Hadad son of Hazael the towns he had taken in battle from his father Jehoahaz. Three times Jehoash defeated him, and so he recovered the Israelite towns.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:25
rsbNotes.text: 13:25 Three times Joash defeated him. Fulfilling the last prophecy of Elisha (v. 19), the victories of Joash stopped the Syrian expansion. Later, Jeroboam II would also defeat the Syrians (14:25).

verses.text: In the second year of Jehoash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel, Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah began to reign.
He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem twenty-nine years. His mother's name was Jehoaddin; she was from Jerusalem.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:1
rsbNotes.text: 14:1 In the second year of Joash. That is, 796 b.c.

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, but not as his father David had done. In everything he followed the example of his father Joash.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:3
rsbNotes.text:
14:3 he did what was right in the eyes of the Lord. He followed the laws of the covenant (1 Kin. 2:3 note).

yet not like David his father. See note 1 Kin. 11:4.

verses.text: The high places, however, were not removed; the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense there.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:4
rsbNotes.text: 14:4 the high places were not removed. Amaziah is one of several kings of Judah praised by the author, but his praise is qualified because Amaziah tolerated worship at the hilltop shrines (1 Kin. 3:2 note).

verses.text: After the kingdom was firmly in his grasp, he executed the officials who had murdered his father the king.

Yet he did not put the sons of the assassins to death, in accordance with what is written in the Book of the Law of Moses where the LORD commanded: "Fathers shall not be put to death for their children, nor children put to death for their fathers; each is to die for his own sins."

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:5
rsbNotes.text: 14:5 struck down his servants. See 12:20, 21.

verses.text: He was the one who defeated ten thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt and captured Sela in battle, calling it Joktheel, the name it has to this day.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:7
rsbNotes.text:
14:7 struck down ten thousand Edomites. This major victory temporarily reversed earlier losses (cf. 8:20–22; 2 Chr. 25:11, 12).

Valley of Salt. Probably this is the salt flats south of the Dead Sea (cf. 2 Sam. 8:13; Ps. 60:title).

Sela. The Septuagint (Old Testament Greek translation) identifies Sela (meaning “rock” in Hebrew) as Petra (meaning “rock” in Greek), located along the Rift Valley about fifty miles south of the Dead Sea. Some modern scholars place it in northern Edomite territory near Bozrah (Judg. 1:36).

to this day. This phrase reflects a time before the Jews were taken captive to Babylon (1 Kin. 8:8 note).

verses.text: Then Amaziah sent messengers to Jehoash son of Jehoahaz, the son of Jehu, king of Israel, with the challenge: "Come, meet me face to face."

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:8
rsbNotes.text: 14:8 Jehoash. See 13:10–25.

verses.text: But Jehoash king of Israel replied to Amaziah king of Judah: "A thistle in Lebanon sent a message to a cedar in Lebanon, 'Give your daughter to my son in marriage.' Then a wild beast in Lebanon came along and trampled the thistle underfoot.
You have indeed defeated Edom and now you are arrogant. Glory in your victory, but stay at home! Why ask for trouble and cause your own downfall and that of Judah also?"

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:9
rsbNotes.text: 14:9 A thistle. The northern kingdom was larger and more powerful than the southern kingdom (1 Kin. 14:30; 15:16, 17 and notes). In this fable (cf. Judg. 9:8–15) the little thistle (Amaziah) thinks it is equal to a cedar of Lebanon (Jehoash) only to be trampled underfoot.

verses.text: Amaziah, however, would not listen, so Jehoash king of Israel attacked. He and Amaziah king of Judah faced each other at Beth Shemesh in Judah.
Judah was routed by Israel, and every man fled to his home.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:11
rsbNotes.text: 14:11 Beth-shemesh. A city fifteen miles west of Jerusalem (1 Kin. 4:9).

verses.text: Jehoash king of Israel captured Amaziah king of Judah, the son of Joash, the son of Ahaziah, at Beth Shemesh. Then Jehoash went to Jerusalem and broke down the wall of Jerusalem from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate-a section about six hundred feet long.
He took all the gold and silver and all the articles found in the temple of the LORD and in the treasuries of the royal palace. He also took hostages and returned to Samaria.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:13
rsbNotes.text:
14:13 Jehoash . . . captured Amaziah. Jehoash probably brought Amaziah back to Samaria (v. 14). Amaziah was forced to stay there until the death of Jehoash (v. 17).

Ephraim Gate. This main gate was in the north wall (Neh. 8:16; 12:39).

Corner Gate. At the northwest angle of the wall (2 Chr. 26:9; Jer. 31:38; Zech. 14:10).

verses.text: As for the other events of the reign of Jehoash, what he did and his achievements, including his war against Amaziah king of Judah, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:15
rsbNotes.text: 14:15 Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

verses.text: Jehoash rested with his fathers and was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel. And Jeroboam his son succeeded him as king.
Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah lived for fifteen years after the death of Jehoash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:16
rsbNotes.text: 14:16 Jeroboam. Jeroboam II, who ruled from 793–753 b.c. (vv. 23–29).

verses.text: As for the other events of Amaziah's reign, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:18
rsbNotes.text: 14:18 Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

verses.text: They conspired against him in Jerusalem, and he fled to Lachish, but they sent men after him to Lachish and killed him there.
He was brought back by horse and was buried in Jerusalem with his fathers, in the City of David.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:19
rsbNotes.text: 14:19 Lachish. An important city of Judah fifteen miles west of Hebron.

verses.text: Then all the people of Judah took Azariah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king in place of his father Amaziah.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:21
rsbNotes.text: 14:21 sixteen years old. Probably Azariah was made king during his father’s absence, and the reigns of father and son overlapped for many years (vv. 13, 17).

verses.text: He was the one who rebuilt Elath and restored it to Judah after Amaziah rested with his fathers.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:22
rsbNotes.text: 14:22 Elath. A seaport on the Gulf of Aqaba, Elath was first used by Solomon to foster sea trade with other nations (1 Kin. 9:26–28). Because Amaziah defeated Edom (v. 7), his son Azariah was able to rebuild Elath and again use it as a Judean port (cf. 1 Kin. 22:47–49; 2 Kin. 8:20–22; 16:6).

verses.text: In the fifteenth year of Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah, Jeroboam son of Jehoash king of Israel became king in Samaria, and he reigned forty-one years.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:23
rsbNotes.text:
14:23 In the fifteenth year of Amaziah. That is, 782 b.c., the beginning of Jeroboam’s independent reign.

Jeroboam. That is, Jeroboam II. For the reign of Jeroboam I, see 1 Kin. 11:26–14:19.

forty-one years. That is, 793–753 b.c. It is likely that Jeroboam II was co-regent with his father Jehoash for eleven years at the start of his reign (Introduction to 1 Kings: Characteristics and Themes).

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the LORD and did not turn away from any of the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he had caused Israel to commit.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:24
rsbNotes.text: 14:24 the sins of Jeroboam. See note 1 Kin. 12:30. Politically and economically, Jeroboam II was one of the most successful monarchs in the entire history of the northern kingdom (v. 25). He forced the Syrians to retreat from Damascus into central Syria. He also expanded Israelite territory toward the Dead Sea.

verses.text: He was the one who restored the boundaries of Israel from Lebo Hamath to the Sea of the Arabah, in accordance with the word of the LORD, the God of Israel, spoken through his servant Jonah son of Amittai, the prophet from Gath Hepher.
The LORD had seen how bitterly everyone in Israel, whether slave or free, was suffering; there was no one to help them.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:25
rsbNotes.text:
14:25 Lebo-hamath. This area was the northernmost part of Israel (Num. 13:21; 34:7–9; 1 Kin. 8:65 note).

Sea of the Arabah. That is, the Dead Sea (Josh. 3:16; 12:3). Jeroboam expanded Israel’s territory to the south on the eastern side of the Jordan, the lands of Ammon and Moab. Jeroboam II controlled more land than any previous northern king (cf. Amos 6:14).

Jonah the son of Amittai. See Introduction to Jonah.

Gath-hepher. About fourteen miles west of the southern part of the Sea of Chinneroth (Galilee). See Josh. 19:13.

verses.text: And since the LORD had not said he would blot out the name of Israel from under heaven, he saved them by the hand of Jeroboam son of Jehoash.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:27
rsbNotes.text: 14:27 blot out the name. In the ancient Near East names were erased from inscriptions as a sign of rejection or loss of power (Ex. 32:32, 33; Deut. 9:14; 29:20).

verses.text: As for the other events of Jeroboam's reign, all he did, and his military achievements, including how he recovered for Israel both Damascus and Hamath, which had belonged to Yaudi, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:28
rsbNotes.text:
14:28 Damascus. The capital of Syria.

Hamath. That is, “Lebo-hamath.” See note on v. 25.

Judah. David and Solomon had controlled both Damascus and Hamath (2 Sam. 8:6; 1 Kin. 8:65; 2 Chr. 8:3).

Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

verses.text: Jeroboam rested with his fathers, the kings of Israel. And Zechariah his son succeeded him as king.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:29
rsbNotes.text: 14:29 Zechariah. On the reign of Zechariah, see 15:8–12.
